description:
The most versatile note-taking app that I have encountered.
There is also a very active community developing plugins for it.

As a developer, I use the git sync, code/syntax highlighting , and diagram drawing plugins.

The notes are in markdown, so they can be edited in other apps if needed.

description: Helped me tone down my usage of text editors for notes to a single one, it offers great Latex support for academic use.
Useful for making your own knowledge base in an user friendly environment

It's very usuable application. Has graph-view, wiki-links, split views, fast creating and editing md notes. 
It's the markdown ide )))
awesome app for notes
It has nice features for editing, customisation and reading.

I am using it since several months and it fit all my needs. It is free, there is no need to create accounts, all notes are stored locally, there are a lot of youtube videos how to use it and it is very customizable.
summary: This app is awesome! It has everything you could want

description: I do a lot of programming and like to intertwine taking notes with code in a simple manner. I'm sticking to private Discord servers, not being impressed with this. However, the graphing software included with this is going to be useful for me in the future.
summary: Appeals to a narrow group of people

description: Really nice note taking app
An actual hidden gem

It is not as light as Ghostwriter, but it is not bloated either. The plugin system is amazing and I appriciate that I can make my own theme too with some css knowladge (there are many to choose from too btw). You really should give it a try!
summary: It helps you become more organized

description: I feel that this app is really oriented to those who like taking short notes interlinked with each other. The graph view really shines only for these users. Otherwise, it is pretty serviceable as a latex+text editor. The plugins and themes available are plenty and still growing. Highly recommended.

Great tool focues on connecting ideas through links and tags. Graph view to visualize how all your knowledge is connected makes it harder to loose things. The app uses a plugin based design and the community is incredible, so it's a veryd customizable experience. I highly recomend.
I use it everyday for my studies. SUPER customizable.
Love this application! My favourite for the zettlekasten note taking system.

This application is extremely useful for employing the zettelkasten method. Although I refrain from using their zettelkasten filename plugin, since it violates basic principles in the method, if simply using your own id-system it works very well, and the graph view helps to keep everythiong connected, by shooing stuff that are dangling outside the web.
summary: Great for using the zettelkasten method!

description: Best implementation of this kind of note taking application that I have used. linking notes together feels natural and awesome
summary: Improving all the time, works great right now too

description: Haven't fully dived into it but it's very well featured and put together. Doesn't look native on my setup because it fails to follow the system theme, which even if it makes me really picky probably means I won't use it much.
summary: Full Featured, Runs Well, Doesn't Use System Theme

description: Allowing link to other note makes it very good for lecture note and keeping brainstorming result
With this you can put your brain in Markdown files!
summary: Amazing! It can do almost everything!

description: Good Markdown editor and note-taking app. Love that it operates on plain-text only and saves automatically. Can seamlessly display images as well which makes it great for knowledge collection.

Obsidian introduced me to Markdown, and I fell in love instantly. It's absolutely astounding how useful the app is for organizing and cataloging all of your notes, and their Sync offering makes transfering and updating your notebooks between different platforms literally seemless and so convenient. One of my favorite elements of Obsidian is that you own your own material, it's all readily accessible as simple .md files, which means you can manage your own Sync if you'd like, for free, using a cloud service or even physical portable media. Obsidian changed the way I take notes.

Obsidian is a far better note taking solution than Evernote, OneNote, or Keep. First, while not open source, it is built on data privacy. Second, you have ultimate control - backlinks, to do tracking, daily notes and other periodic notes. The markdown approach rocks - keeps you focused on what your capturing, not on how it looks.
summary: Fantastic - better than Evernote or Onenote

description: Just needs live markup rendering. Other than that, this editor is amazing. Makes me wish more apps linked their files as easily.

This is a full-blown markdown complete with math rendering. It has some interesting ideas around it, such as support for Vim key bindings, making templates, backlinking, and more.

A lot of people are using the app for implementing PKM systems like the Zettelkasten method. We'll see how it goes fast forward 5 years ...

It also has a vibrant development ecosystem for plugins at the moment. There's one cool plugin there (Excalidraw) that allows sketching hand-drawn diagrams natively.
summary: Hands Down the Best Markdown Editor!

description: I can highly recommend this app to keep your notes. After moving from Google Keep to OneNote through Notion and ending here, I can assure you that this app is the best, safest and most customizable way to store your thoughts!

I believe many people are not aware, that Obsidian is not open source software. 

As an alternative I would recommend Logseq
Unfortunately it does not provide encryption features.
Not free software.
its not open source. But its fast. if you don't trust. Just put firewall.
Just perfect, thanks!
So powerful! It takes some time to get used to it, but once you grasp the concept you will find it invaluable
summary: You will wonder how ever got along without it

description: I like it very much by the way the linking between notes works and how the graph displays the connections. What I do not like is that it's not open-source. 4/5 stars
summary: Very cool knowledge management app. Not open-source tho

description:
It's great, but can't get my ".bashrc" proxy settings.
How can i set up a proxies?

I've been finding that the built-in editor that GitLab has is no longer suiting my needs. So, I started looking for locally-installed alternatives.

I found out about Obsidian because Chris Titus Tech mentioned it in a video comparing Arch, Debian, and Fedora. So I gave it a try. I found it difficult to do some of the things that I usually do extremely easily on GitLab. For example, copying the "path" to a header (for appending to URLs). On GitLab, you can just go into preview mode, click the link button next to the header, and copy it from the (now updated) URL in the address bar. I could not even find how to do this in Obsidian. It might be buried in menus somewhere. Not sure. But that's such an important feature to me that it should be the first button in the right-click context menu.

I love the beautiful animations and the automatic visual formatting, but I feel less productive than I do on GitLab's built-in editor. It also has features that I would like... that do not function on Linux solely because of how they were implemented (for example, transluscent windows). The fact that they force you to use their built-in window decorations (that are very Windows-esque) does not give me confidence that they are interested in implementing those features for Linux. If I had to guess, they used libraries that are not supported on Linux to achive those things. So adding support would likely mean rewriting the features or adding OS-specific code for Linux, utilizing compatible libraries. I guess adding "Not supported on Linux" to a label is easier than that.

What I settled on in the meantime is Apostrophe. It uses GTK, so it works really well on Linux and plays relatively nice with custom window decorations, icons, and themes. It has a half-width preview mode (half the screen is source, the other half is the preview), which I actually prefer over the live preview (this is just preference). Then, I can just right click a header, click "Inspect Element", right click the HTML element it highlights, hover over "Copy", and click "Selector Path". In my opinion, this is how it should be. Intuitive. Either by design or by copying existing paradigms (like web browsers). I'm leaving this comparison here so that hopefully the Obsidian devs can take that feedback and make it much more intuitive to achieve something that I do really frequently whenever I'm editing markdown files.

My biggest problem with Obsidian is that it feels really useful and polished (the animations are really slick), but it also feels like it's getting in my way. Like, I'm sure it has a ton of features... but they're all buried seemingly for the sake of aesthetics. Bottom line, I just feel less productive when I use Obsidian and that's a problem.
summary: Not a fan. Pretty... but convoluted (or lacking)

description: Also useful for knoeledge bases in general

Well, like one said before; it is not open source. But still I like it athough it is not following the themeing standards like GTK or KDEtheme on Linux. Well, I'm shifting to the open source alternative, when it is available for Linux.
